conclusion: Known data: R₁ = 20 Ω, Internal (ohmic) resistance of the motor: R₂ = 10 Ω, Ammeter reading with the switch open: I₀ = 0.50 A (current only through R₁)
Find the supply voltage U: U = I₀ · R₁ = 0.50 A × 20 Ω = 10 V
Close the switch. The motor branch is now connected in parallel with R₁.

premise: U = 10 V, R₁ = 20 Ω, R₂ = 10 Ω
conclusion: If the motor behaved like an ordinary 10 Ω resistor, the parallel combination of 20 Ω and 10 Ω would carry I_calc = U / (R₁ || R₂) = 10 V / (20 Ω × 10 Ω / (20 Ω + 10 Ω)) = 10 V / 6.67 Ω ≈ 1.5 A
The circuit power in that purely resistive case would be P_calc = U · I_calc ≈ 10 V × 1.5 A = 15 W.
Real motor behavior: Once the motor begins to turn, a back-emf is generated.

premise: Back-emf opposes the applied voltage, motor draws less current than a simple 10 Ω resistor.
conclusion: I_real < 1.5 A ⇒ P_real = U · I_real < 15 W.
The actual electric power consumed by the circuit after the switch is closed is smaller than 15 W.
